facts.text: Appellant was Ruler of erstwhile Faridkot State.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant who was admittedly a Ruler of the erstwhile Faridkot State challenged the assessments made against him for the years 1946-47 and 1947-48

facts.text: Assessee claimed immunity from taxation as Ruler of Faridkot State, sovereign not assessee under Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee objected to these proceedings and companytended before the Income-tax Officer that he being a Ruler of the Faridkot State was immune from taxation on every source of income.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessee was immune from tax under the Indian Income-tax Act on his private income viz., dividends and interest income as also the Capital Gains earned in British India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Nizam case holding that Indian rulers lacked international personality; no immunity under international law; statutory exemptions only where provided.

holdings.text: Rulers of erstwhile native States did not enjoy privileges as Heads of States recognised as Members of the family of nations in International Law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Native states subject to British paramountcy; status as international personalities negatived by 1891 notification; Viceroy statement on supremacy.

holdings.text: Status of assessee as ruler of Indian State could not be equated with that of a sovereign in international law.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has specifically While rejecting, the second contention addressed on behalf of the assessee ruled, that the status of the assessee as a ruler of the Indian State could. not be equated with that of a sovereign in international law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference enables consideration of status; native rulers under paramountcy lacked international personality per historical documents and Nizam precedent.

holdings.text: Rulers of an Indian State could only avail of immunity from taxation if recognised as international personalities which they are not; exemptions must be under relevant taxing Acts.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for us to examine this position because even if there was such an immunity the Rulers of an Indian State could only avail of it, if they are recognised as international personalities which, as we have seen, they are not. Any exemptions which they may be given, must, in our view be under the relevant taxing Acts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming arguendo immunity for true sovereigns under intl law, Indian rulers lacked personality; specific statutory exemptions like Sec 60 IT Act imply general liability.

holdings.text: Status of native States as International personalities was negatived.

anchor.surface_text: The status of these native States as International personalities was negatived. in the Notification of the Government published in Gazette of India Part 1, dated 21st August, 1891

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government notification in Gazette explicitly negatived international personality; paramount supremacy of British Crown implied subordination.

holdings.text: Immunity from legal proceedings for ruling princes codified in CPC Sections 84-87, not absolute and not derived from international law.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 433 of the Code of Civil Procedure of 1882 and subsequently Sections 84 to 87 of the Civil Procedure Code of 1908 deal with these matters.... holdings.reasoning_summary: Common law immunity legislated in Indian CPC; consent of Central Govt required for suits; distinguishes from tax immunity.
